CONTRACT OF EMPLOYMENT

Date: {{#doc_var name="document_date" class="datepicker"}}Date of agreement{{/doc_var}}

Employer: {{#doc_var name="employer_name"}}Employer name{{/doc_var}} of {{#doc_var name="employer_address"}}Full employer address{{/doc_var}} (the "Company")

Employee: {{#doc_var name="employee_name"}}Employee name{{/doc_var}} of {{#doc_var name="employee_address"}}Full employee address{{/doc_var}}
  1. GENERAL
    1. The following particulars are given to you in accordance with the terms of the Employment Rights Act 1996 and will constitute your written statement of particulars of employment (as required by the Act) and your contract of employment (the "Contract").
    2. This Contract also supersedes any previous agreements between you and the Company.
  2. CONTINUOUS EMPLOYMENT
    1. {{#doc_select name="employment_date_start_offerletter"}} Subject to satisfaction of any conditions set out in your offer letter, your employment under this Contract will begin on {{#doc_var name="employment_date_start" class="datepicker"}}Employment date start{{/doc_var}}. {option} Your employment under this Contract will begin on {{#doc_var name="employment_date_start" class="datepicker"}}Employment date start{{/doc_var}}. {{/doc_select}} {{#doc_select name="continuous_employment"}} Your period of continuous employment with the Company {{#doc_choice name="my_variable_name" choices="began,will begin" is_static=true}}{{/doc_choice}} on {{#doc_var name="employment_date_start" class="datepicker"}}Employment date start{{/doc_var}}. {option} No employment with a previous employer counts as part of your period of continuous employment with the Company. {{/doc_select}}
      2. {{#doc_select name="probationary_period" can_toggle="true"}}
    2. The first {{#doc_var name="probationary_period_months"}}Number of months{{/doc_var}} months of your employment will be a probationary period. During this time your performance and conduct will be monitored. At the end of the probationary period your performance and conduct will be reviewed and if found satisfactory your appointment will be confirmed. If, however, your performance or conduct is deemed unsatisfactory at that time in the opinion of the Company, the probationary period may be extended or your employment terminated on {{#doc_var name="probationary_period_weeks_notice"}}Number of weeks notice during probation{{/doc_var}} week's notice in the Company's absolute discretion.
      3. {{/doc_select}}
  3. Job title/duties
    1. You are employed as {{#doc_var name="job_title"}}Job title{{/doc_var}} and report to {{#doc_var name="employee_report_to"}}Employee reports to{{/doc_var}}. Your main duties in this role will be {{#doc_var name="job_role_description"}}Basic job description{{/doc_var}}. The Company may require you to perform such other or additional duties or to undertake a different role of similar status as the needs of the business dictate.
      2. {{#doc_select name="outside_activities" can_toggle="true"}}
    2. You shall not while employed by the Company under the terms of this Contract without the prior written consent of the Company, be directly or indirectly engaged, concerned or interested in any business, profession or occupation other than that of the Company and you will not engage in any activity or have any interest during or outside working hours which may affect your ability to perform your duties under this Contract or may constitute a conflict of interest with your employment under this Contract.
      3. {{/doc_select}}
  4. Place and hours of work
    1. You shall carry out your duties at {{#doc_var name="primary_place_of_work"}}Primary place of work{{/doc_var}} but you may be required to work (on either a temporary or permanent basis) and travel to such places as may be requested from time to time by the Company (whether inside or outside the United Kingdom).
    2. Your normal working hours are between {{#doc_var name="normal_hours_of_work"}}Normal hours of work{{/doc_var}} inclusive with one hour for lunch. In certain circumstances it may be necessary to adjust, change or exceed the hours in order to ensure that your duties under the terms of your employment are properly performed in accordance with the needs of the business. You may be required to work such additional hours as are necessary for the proper performance of your duties without additional remuneration.
  5. Salary
    1. Your gross annual salary will be {{#doc_var name="salary"}}Annual salary{{/doc_var}} which will be paid monthly in arrears direct by credit transfer into your bank account.
    2. Your salary will be reviewed by the Company annually but there is no commitment to increase your salary on review.
  6. Deductions from pay
    You agree that the Company may deduct sums from time to time owed to it by you from any payment due to you from the Company.
  7. Holidays
    1. In addition to the statutory holidays, which are New Year's Day, Good Friday, Easter Monday, Spring Bank Holiday, May Day, Late Summer Bank Holiday, Christmas Day and Boxing Day, you will be entitled to {{#doc_var name="annual_holiday"}} Annual holiday allowance{{/doc_var}} working days' holiday in each holiday year. The Companyâ€™s holiday year runs from {{#doc_var name="annual_holiday_period"}}Annual holiday year e.g. Jan 1st - December 31st {{/doc_var}}.
    2. You may not take as holiday more than {{#doc_var name="maximum_consecutive_holiday_days"}}Maximum consecutive days of holiday{{/doc_var}} working days consecutively out of your entitlement without the prior consent of the Company and any holidays must be taken at times previously agreed by the Company. Such agreement is to be obtained before you have committed yourself to booking a holiday or made any other positive arrangements. You will not be permitted to carry over any unused holiday entitlement into the following holiday year except with the express written consent of the Company and you will not be entitled to payment for any such unused holiday entitlement (save on termination of employment).
    3. On termination of your employment, if you have taken more or less than your annual holiday entitlement an appropriate adjustment shall be made to any payment of salary or benefits from the Company to you. For these purposes, a day's salary will be calculated at the rate of 1/260th of your annual salary.
    4. The Company reserves the right to require you to take any outstanding holiday during your notice period.
  8. Sick pay arrangements
    1. In the case of absence from work due to sickness, injury or other incapacity you or someone on your behalf must notify {{#doc_var name="sickness_notification"}}Person to be notified if employee is sick{{/doc_var}} before {{#doc_var name="sickness_notification_time"}}Time they must notify company by{{/doc_var}} a.m. on the first day of absence stating the cause of the absence and its likely duration. After the first day of absence you should keep the Company updated on a regular basis (at least every two days) with your progress. In cases of absence of up to six days you should submit a self certification form to the Company and in the case of an absence lasting seven days or more (including weekends) you will be required to produce a doctor's certificate for your absence and for each subsequent period of seven days thereafter.
    2. Subject to your compliance in full with the Company's sick leave policy, the Company will pay you {{#doc_var name="sickness_payment"}}Sickness payment{{/doc_var}}.1
    3. The Company reserves the right to require you to attend a medical examination conducted by a doctor nominated by the Company and you will authorise such doctor to disclose and discuss with the Company the results of the examination and any matters arising from it.
    4. The payment of any kind of sick pay shall not affect the Company's power to terminate your employment.
  9. Pension
    1. The Company shall comply with its duties under the Pensions Act 2008. Details of any pension scheme applicable to your employment shall be provided to you by {{#doc_var name="pension_info_person_responsible"}}Person responsible for pension scheme{{/doc_var}}.2
    2. {{#doc_choice name="contracting_out_certificate" choices="A,No" is_static=true}}{{/doc_choice}} contracting out certificate in relation to your employment is in force.
  10. Termination of Employment
      {{#doc_select name="probationary_period_length" can_toggle="true"}}
    1. During the {{#doc_var name="probationary_period_months"}}Lengths of probationary period (months){{/doc_var}} months' probationary period the notice required by either the Company or yourself to terminate your employment will be {{#doc_var name="probationary_period_notice_weeks"}}Probation period notice length{{/doc_var}} week.
      2. {{/doc_select}}
    2. The notice (in writing) required by either the Company or you to terminate your employment will be {{#doc_var name="normal_employment_notice"}}Notice period length{{/doc_var}}.
      3. {{#doc_select name="notice_period_payment" can_toggle="true"}}
    3. The Company reserves the right at any time, in its absolute discretion, to terminate your employment by paying you a sum equal to your basic salary for the relevant period of notice. The payment shall consist solely of your basic salary for the period of notice and shall exclude any other entitlements or benefits referable to your employment and shall be subject to deductions for income tax and national insurance contributions as appropriate.
      4. {{/doc_select}}
    4. Nothing in this Contract prevents the Company from terminating your employment summarily (without notice) or otherwise if you commit any serious breach of the terms of your employment or of this Contract or in the event that you:
      1. are guilty of any gross misconduct affecting the business of the Company;
      2. commit any serious or repeated breach or non-observance of any of the provisions of this Contract or refuse or neglect to comply with any reasonable and lawful directions of the Company;
      3. are, in the reasonable opinion of the Company, negligent in the performance of your duties;
      4. are declared bankrupt or make any arrangement with or for the benefit of your creditors or have a county court administration order made against you under the County Court Act 1984;
      5. are convicted of any criminal offence (other than an offence under any road traffic legislation in the United Kingdom or elsewhere for which a fine or non-custodial penalty is imposed);
      6. become of unsound mind (which includes lacking capacity under any statute relating to mental health);
      7. cease to be eligible to work in the United Kingdom;
      8. are guilty of any fraud or dishonesty or act in any manner which in the opinion of the Company brings or is likely to bring you or the Company into disrepute or is materially adverse to the interests of the Company;
      9. you commit any act of theft or other dishonesty or violence either at or outside work;
      10. you commit any act of deliberate discrimination or harassment of a protected characteristic (as such expression is defined in section 4 of the Equality Act 2010); or
      11. you commit any other act warranting summary termination at common law.
    5. On the termination of your employment, or at any other time in accordance with instructions given to you by the Company, you will immediately return to the Company all equipment, correspondence, records, specifications, software, models, notes, reports and other documents and any copies thereof and any other property belonging to the Company which are in your possession or under your control.
  11. Confidential and Business Information
    1. For the purposes of this clause, "Confidential Information" shall mean all trade secrets, business methods, corporate strategy, business development plans, terms of business with actual or potential customers and/or suppliers, annual budgets, management accounts and other financial information, research reports, details of financial standing of customers, business contacts, plans, designs, software, specifications, price lists, lists of actual and potential clients and suppliers, correspondence, manuscripts, records (in whatever medium), documents, accounts and papers of any description, contact details of employees and directors and details of remuneration and benefits, any other property of the Company or any client of the Company, notes, memoranda, records and writings whether made by you or otherwise within your possession or under your control (or as appropriate your personal representatives) relating to the affairs and business of the Company or any clients of the Company.3
    2. You hereby undertake to the Company that (save as expressly ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction) neither during the course of your employment (except in the proper performance of your duties) nor at any time after the termination of your employment will you directly or indirectly:
      1. use for your own purposes or those of any other person, company, business entity or other organisation whatsoever; or
      2. disclose to any person, company, business entity or other organisation whatsoever

      any Confidential Information.
    3. The obligations contained in clause 11.2 above shall cease to apply to any information or knowledge which may subsequently come into the public domain after the termination of your employment other than by way of unauthorised disclosure.
    4. Nothing in this Contract shall operate to prevent you making a "protected disclosure" pursuant to Part IVA of the Employment Rights Act 1996.
  12. Data Protection
    1. The Company will hold computer records and personnel files relating to you. These will include your employment application, references, bank details, performance appraisals, holiday and sickness records, salary reviews and remuneration details and other records, (which may, where necessary, include sensitive data relating to your health, and data held for ethnic monitoring purposes). The Company requires such personal data for personnel, administration and management purposes and to comply with its obligations regarding the keeping of employee/worker records. Your right of access to this data is as prescribed by law.
    2. You hereby agree that the Company may process personal data relating to you for personnel, administration and management purposes (including, where necessary, sensitive data relating to your health, and data held for ethnic monitoring purposes) and may, when necessary for those purposes, make such data available to its advisers, to parties providing products and/or services to the Company (including, without limitation IT systems suppliers, pension, benefits and payroll administrators), to regulatory authorities (including HM Revenue & Customs), to any potential purchasers of the Company or its business (on a confidential basis) and as required by law. Further, you hereby agree that the Company may transfer such data to and from Group Companies including any Group Companies located outside the European Economic Area.
  13. DISCIPLINARY AND GRIEVANCE PROCEDURES
    1. The Company's disciplinary and grievance procedure (which may be updated from time to time) is available from {{#doc_var name="disciplinary_procedure_available_from"}}Disciplinary procedure available from{{/doc_var}}. {{#doc_select name="disciplinary_procedure_contractual" can_toggle="true"}}The procedure is non-contractual.{{/doc_select}}
    2. The Company reserves the right to suspend you with pay for a period of no longer than is reasonably necessary for the purposes of investigating any allegation relating to your conduct.
  14. COLLECTIVE AGREEMENTS {{#doc_select name="collective_agreements" can_toggle="true"}} There are no collective agreements which affect the terms and conditions of your employment. {option} There are collective agreements which affect the terms and conditions of your employment, a copy of which are available from {{#doc_var name="collective_agreements_location"}}Terms and conditions location{{/doc_var}}. {{/doc_select}}
  15. Governing Law and Jurisdiction
    This Contract shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of England and the parties submit to the exclusive jurisdiction of the English Courts.

=========DOC ENDS ============ Opening note: This contract of employment is appropriate for a non-executive employee. It includes the required statutory particulars under section 1 of the Employment Rights Act 1996, along with optional wording in square brackets, which an employer may wish to include. As this contract of employment is designed for non-executive employees, more detailed clauses such as garden leave, intellectual property, restrictive covenants etc. have not been included. {{#help_for varname="continuous_employment"}} One of the statutory particulars that is required to be provided is the date when the employeeâ€™s period of continuous employment began, taking into account any employment with a previous employer which counts towards that period.{{/help_for}} {{#help_for varname="probationary_period"}} A probationary period at the start of the employment may be of benefit to the employer, allowing the employer to dismiss on minimum notice (usually 1 week) if an employeeâ€™s performance or conduct is unsatisfactory. {{/help_for}} {{#help_for varname="outside_activities"}} An outside interest clause is designed to control an employeeâ€™s outside activities during the course of employment. {{/help_for}} {{#help_for varname="normal_hours_of_work"}} For example: 9:30am to 5:30pm Mondays to Fridays. {{/help_for}} {{#help_for varname="annual_holiday"}} The minimum statutory holiday entitlement is 5.6 working weeksâ€™ paid annual leave per year (equivalent to 28 days for a full-time employee), including public and bank holidays. As such, in addition to the public holidays referred to in clause 7.1, 20 working daysâ€™ holiday will need to be provided in order to satisfy the minimum statutory holiday entitlement for an employee who works 5 days a week. However, an employer can choose to give a more generous contractual holiday entitlement. {{/help_for}} {{#help_for varname="sickness_payment"}} The employer will need to pay statutory sick pay (SSP), provided that the employee is eligible and satisfies the qualification requirements. Employers may choose to pay employees company sick pay in excess of SSP. {{/help_for}} {{#help_for varname="pension_info_person_responsible"}}The employer will need to be mindful of the pension auto-enrolment regime, and will need to comply with its duties when it reaches its staging date. {{/help_for}} {{#help_for varname="probationary_period_length"}} To be deleted if the probationary period in clause 2.3 is not used.{{/help_for}} {{#help_for varname="contracting_out_certificate"}} One of the statutory particulars that is required to be provided is whether or not a contracting out certificate is in place. {{/help_for}} {{#help_for varname="notice_period_payment"}} A payment in lieu of notice (PILON) clause is a useful tool as it allows the employer to end the employment with immediate effect avoiding having the employee actually work his/her notice without the dismissal being a breach of contract. Careful consideration should be given before including a PILON clause, as they may not always be appropriate and the PILON can relate to salary only or salary and benefits. {{/help_for}} {{#help_for varname="collective_agreements"}} One of the statutory particulars that is required to be provided is details of any collective agreements which affect the terms and conditions of employment. A collective agreement is an agreement or arrangement between the employer or an employerâ€™s association and one or more trade union. {{/help_for}}
